longDescription:
Ise, Mie Prefecture, Japan Ise Grand Shrine (Ise Jingu) is the most sacred shrine in Japan and the spiritual heart of Shinto,
                Japan's indigenous religion. Set within a vast ancient forest of cryptomeria cedars covering over
                5,500 hectares, the shrine complex comprises 125 shrines centered on the Inner Shrine (Naiku), dedicated
                to Amaterasu Omikami, the Sun Goddess and divine ancestor of the Imperial family, and the Outer Shrine
                (Geku), dedicated to Toyouke Omikami, goddess of agriculture and industry. Founded nearly 2,000 years
                ago according to tradition, Ise Jingu embodies the essence of Shinto's reverence for nature, purity,
                and the continuity of Japanese culture across millennia.
description: Ise Grand Shrine (Ise Jingu) is the most sacred shrine in Japan and the spiritual heart of Shinto, the indigenous religion that venerates the kami (divine spirits) inhabiting all aspects of nature. Nestled within an ancient forest of towering cryptomeria cedars spanning over 5,500 hectares in Mie Prefecture, this vast complex comprises 125 individual shrines centered on two main sanctuaries. The Inner Shrine (Naiku) enshrines Amaterasu Omikami, the Sun Goddess and divine ancestress of the Imperial family, while housing the sacred Yata no Kagami (Eight-Sided Mirror), one of Japan's Three Imperial Regalia. The Outer Shrine (Geku) honors Toyouke Omikami, goddess of agriculture and sacred food offerings. What makes Ise Jingu unique among the world's religious sites is its remarkable tradition of Shikinen Sengu - the complete reconstruction of the shrine buildings every 20 years, a practice maintained for over 1,300 years. This ritual ensures the eternal renewal of the kami's dwelling and the transmission of ancient construction techniques across generations. Founded according to tradition nearly 2,000 years ago, the shrine embodies Shinto's core principles: reverence for nature, ritual purity, and the living connection between the Japanese people, their land, and the divine.
